body:
+1
Is there a way to preserve CDATA?
Thank you
I think we're doing the right thing per the spec (https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#cdata-section-state) which treats the contents as literal character tokens. But browsers massage them into comments.
@jhy Thanks for investigating! The spec you posted is a HTML spec. In my case however, we used Jsoup for parsing and serializing an XHTML document. Jsoup was advertised as an XML parser, right?

@ataraxie it's the same thing for XML. CData is an encoding mechanism, similar to escapes. That data is still destined for the DOM. The problem here is in serialization; you expect the CData input to be re-serialized back into CData.

I think that's the right approach. We need to track data sections and make sure they serialize back into CData.

That's right. Let me clarify: we are using Jsoup to replace content in an XHTML document. To be more exact, we're replacing content of pages in [Atlassian Confluence](https://www.atlassian.com/de/software/confluence). The storage format of the page content is XHTML. Upon page view this XHTML is rendered using different rendering mechanisms. Now, there is some data in the XHTML code that is stored in CDATA meta tags. If this is not present, the page won't render correctly. That means if we do a Parse - Manipulate - Serialize and the CDATA is gone, pages won't render correctly. This bug has actually been quite a problem for us, since there were suddenly corrupt pages in our Confluence and we had a hard time figuring out what the problem was.

We already repaired everything in our instance, so it's cool. I just created this issue because I don't want anyone else to experience the same problems. So It'd be nice if this was fixed somehow :wink:

Yep. We want to round-trip the HTML. And that's competing with we want to decode CData into text for mining / querying. 

I think as browser's typically treat as comments (in that the exclude it from the text presented), we should handle this similarly to script tags. I.e. available with a .data() call, but otherwise excluded, and serialized back to CData.
@jhy ,@ataraxie .. any answer for the above problem? Thanks in advance.
Not from my side at the moment. I guess it's a decision of the Jsoup guys in how to handle this :relaxed:
